body:
> > After running `deploy_ssd_gluoncv.py` tutorial under relay, I got `'tuple' object has no attribute 'tojson'` error from `relay/frontend/mxnet.py`. The input of `_from_mxnet_impl(sym, .., ..)` is a tuple of slices of symbols instead of a single symbol.
> 
> Committed the corrections

@Laurawly I don't think we need this commit since a more completed fix already exists: https://github.com/kevinthesun/tvm/blob/RefactorSSDOperator/python/tvm/relay/frontend/mxnet.py#L583-L584 

Also I don't have any issue without your commit, and ci can pass as well. Can you check your local tvm version?

I see, one thing that worries me is that the user might be confused on the divergence.

Perhaps we should do ```topk->top_k``` (to be consistent with keras). Given that our nms is not "standard", maybe we can name it as non_maximum_supression_return_indices
You can try to search on the forum. There are two related threads. https://discuss.tvm.ai/search?q=tensor%20core

@kevinthesun the argument `id_index` or `id_axis` is a bit confusing to me. Would you please explain more in the API summary? The user would use the argument to assign the index of `class_id`, but how about other data layouts that might consist an unknown location of `score`?

Yes, we should move to OPs.
The reason I used FLOPs is to discard the integer multiplications in index expressions.
If we want to count integer OPs, should we discard them?

@tqchen I have added Relay support now.
@srkreddy1238 I have updated docs and added topi test.

@tqchen Are you talking about renaming the api itself to non_maximum_supression_return_indices? I think it's better to keep current name since we support returning either the box indices or boxes.

@liangfu Currently we only support [class_id, score, bl, bt, br, bb] data layout. I'll mention this in docstring. For example, when you converting a gluoncv ssd model, if your original model set id_axis to be 1, it will return an error. However, we still need this argument to indicting when we want to ignore this axis. tf/pt nms inputs doesn't have this axis. In this case, we set id_axis=-1 to ignore it.
can you fix this problem?
My main concern is that ```return_indices``` 's position, as most API do not have such an argument.

It worked for me after patching TVM with the patch I showed above. After some testing I reduced it to the following:

```
diff --git a/python/tvm/contrib/cc.py b/python/tvm/contrib/cc.py
index 0ffa6c42..906bf4cc 100644
--- a/python/tvm/contrib/cc.py
+++ b/python/tvm/contrib/cc.py
@@ -91,7 +91,7 @@ BOOL APIENTRY DllMain( HMODULE hModule,\
         msg = "Compilation error:\n"
         msg += py_str(out)
         raise RuntimeError(msg)
-    link_cmd = ["link"]
+    link_cmd = ["lld-link"]
     link_cmd += ["-dll", "-FORCE:MULTIPLE"]

     for obj in objects:
```

Then apply it:
```
set PATH=%path%;C:\Program Files\Git\bin
bash.exe -c 'patch -p1 ~/AppData/Roaming/Python/Python37/site-packages/tvm-0.5.dev0-py3.7-win-amd64.egg/tvm/contrib/cc.py cc.py.patch'
```

Notes:
1. You must build LLD with LLVM
2. The directory of the built binaries (like lld-link.exe) must added to the path variables (or change to patch to include the full path to lld-link)
We can make it optional and by default returning indices？
I assume no answer means you have other priorities at the moment?

As of now, I am not aware of a concrete plan of supporting the randomization ops. You can refer to the release roadmap (latest #2623) for major features being (going to be) implemented. You are also highly encouraged to contribute. BTW, normally please go to https://discuss.tvm.ai for discussion. Thanks.
Please open a new thread in the discuss forum
As long as the default behavior is the most common one（as in Tf pt) it is fine
thanks

I am very interested in this problem, and I have a few different approaches I want to try out. However, I wonder if requiring intermediate results to be collected is too labor intensive or unnecessary. In the AutoTVM setting, we use domain specific features as they are powerful and allow for transfer learning. However, transfer learning is not as important in this setting, and it could be that blackbox features (e.g., just the scale configuration) may be enough to build a usable machine learning model (just as knob features are usable in AutoTVM). I think if that turns out to already work then we can save a significant amount of effort. It seems slightly expensive to compute both the original graph and annotated graph every time we want to do try a different calibration configuration, so I think it would be great if we could get away with doing even less work :).

I'll send updates on this approach as I get results. You may have already guessed that performance is important as I am first tuning the workloads required for quantization so trying many calibration configurations is not too slow.

> Hi @derisavi , it would be better if you can provide a test case to demonstrate using `tensorize` with `TensorComputeOp`, which is mentioned in your RFC.

That RFC (#2583) is only trying to motivate having a common base class and as one of the reasons I've mentioned tensorization. I think tensorization of `TensorComputeOp` requires its own separate RFC issue. Should I then just create a new issue for that and a testcase there?
@derisavi If tensorization of `TensorComputeOp` need other modification for code, we can leave it to another PR
Huh. I don't think anything changed in `rust/` lately. Maybe a dependency was a missing lockfile somewhere. Isn't semver great? I'll take a look now.

I am not sure how to best go about deferring type inference for the module, if that's what we wanted to do. It could complicate type inference for functions that reference that global if it were not checked when it was added to the module.
@ZihengJiang We have tried to tensorize `TensorComputeOp` and it doesn't work out of the box. It does need more modifications. Should I still put the testcase?
@derisavi Then we can aim at supporting it in this PR, or make sure `tensorize` will throw error for `TensorComputeOp`

That feels very ad hoc. With type conversions you need to work out the type hierarchy otherwise you will quickly end up with computational errors that are impossible to debug. Languages will demand that if a conversion is semantically important it needs to be specified. Otherwise you quickly end up with float64 that capture a default progression, but which will be very inefficiënt.

History tells us that you can't take the short cut, it will bite you. So my two cents is to make the conversion an explicit operator so that the modeler has the control they need. It will also prepare the model for new number systems such as bfloat8, posits, and others yet to be discovered.
@jroesch can you manage this PR as per https://docs.tvm.ai/contribute/committer_guide.html, a good chance to test out your committer rights.

The current IR semantics requires explicit conversion of dtype, which works OK in most cases. I think it might be good to keep it that way. It also helps in cases like @Ravenwater mentioned when we start to add customized data types.
@zhiics can you summarize the discussion, update your post with the latest interface and then tag folks to see if they like it?
@derisavi sounds good, you can also check the testcase for `tensorize`: https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/tests/python/unittest/test_lang_schedule.py#L172
@tqchen the ci fail for mystic reason. do you have any idea?
@tqchen @jroesch @wweic @icemelon9 @yzhliu @FrozenGene both the post and the PR are updated. Please take another look. Any inputs are appreciated:)

I think it might be too strict to assert the types in relation for this case. I understand that making type conversion implicit might bring some burdens in debugging. But it looks to me that providing type hint and leveraging the type solver or having some specific passes to solve determine the type should be a good option.

I agree there are tradeoffs that need to be made. This is like the same trade-off we have to make when thinking about broadcasting in binary operators. Let us list the pros and cons

**Pros of Implicit Casting**
- it makes frontend building relatively easy when dealing with mixed-dtype code

**Pros of Explicit Casting**

- Mixed dtype is relatively rare in deep learning, so one can argue explicit casting is fine.
- It makes support user-defined new floating type easy(e.g. bfloat), which is crucial for accelerators.
- It simplifies the codegen support in the IR
One note: move include/relay/doc.h into src/relay/ir, just to keep it internal and minimum.

I think we are converging :)

- I am not sure if we still need the pass_kind field (could duplicate with the subnode case), opt_level was fine as a field. If we user does not need to know it, it should not be in the base node.
- One important requirement is that the base class (PassNode) should remain stable over time.
   - Do we need to add future meta information to the pass or not?
   - Does it make sense to introduce a PassInfo struct that contains all the meta information (name, node, dependency) and return by GetInfo() @zhiics @jroesch @FrozenGene

@ZihengJiang I added a testcase that asserts that `tensorize` of a loop of a `TensorComputeOp` has no effect, i.e., the loop that is supposed to be tensorized will not be replaced by anything.
The testcase is not complete in the sense that it doesn't generate meaningful code if we eventually support tensorization for `TensorComputeOp`. When we start supporting that type of tensorization, the testcase will fail, and we need to modify it.
@merrymercy I had wrote a test case using tuple, and a test case using adt, higher order function, closure, pattern matching(control flow) and recursion. do i address your issue?
